Amplitude-Varying Perturbation for Balancing Privacy and Utility in Federated Learning

Xin Yuan,Â , Wei Ni,Â , Ming Ding,Â ,
Kang Wei,Â , Jun Li,Â , and H. Vincent Poor,Â  X. Yuan, W. Ni, and M. Ding are with Data61, CSIRO, Sydney, Australia (e-mail: xin.yuan, wei.ni, ming.ding@data61.csiro.au). K. Wei and J. Li are with the School of Electrical and Optical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, China (e-mail: kang.wei, jun.li@njust.edu.cn). H. V. Poor is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544 USA (e-mail: poor@princeton.edu).
Abstract

While preserving the privacy of federated learning (FL), differential privacy (DP) inevitably degrades the utility (i.e., accuracy) of FL due to model perturbations caused by DP noise added to model updates. Existing studies have considered exclusively noise with persistent root-mean-square amplitude and overlooked an opportunity of adjusting the amplitudes to alleviate the adverse effects of the noise. This paper presents a new DP perturbation mechanism with a time-varying noise amplitude to protect the privacy of FL and retain the capability of adjusting the learning performance. Specifically, we propose a geometric series form for the noise amplitude and reveal analytically the dependence of the series on the number of global aggregations and the (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP requirement. We derive an online refinement of the series to prevent FL from premature convergence resulting from excessive perturbation noise. Another important aspect is an upper bound developed for the loss function of a multi-layer perceptron (MLP) trained by FL running the new DP mechanism. Accordingly, the optimal number of global aggregations is obtained, balancing the learning and privacy. Extensive experiments are conducted using MLP, supporting vector machine, and convolutional neural network models on four public datasets. The contribution of the new DP mechanism to the convergence and accuracy of privacy-preserving FL is corroborated, compared to the state-of-the-art Gaussian noise mechanism with a persistent noise amplitude.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, differential privacy, time-varying noise variance, convergence analysis.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) trains machine learning (ML) models at individual devices without the need to surrender any sensitive raw data of the devices to central serversÂ [1]. It provides an effective means of model training without directly leaking private informationÂ [2]. Despite its significant potential for privacy protection, there are still risks of revealing sensitive information in the individual models uploaded to an aggregator (e.g., a central server) on each aggregation round of FL. In particular, the local models learned from the respective local datasets can be reverse-engineered (e.g., by a curious central server) to extract private informationÂ [3, 4]. Notably, ShokriÂ et al.Â [5] demonstrated that private information about local datasets can be derived from trained local models. Moreover, model inversion attacks have been shown to be able to extract private information by using black-box attacks to predict modelsÂ [6, 7].

Privacy-preserving FL is a promising method for solving the above challengesÂ [8, 9, 10, 11, 12]. It incorporates privacy techniques into distributed ML frameworks to deliver a provable guarantee of privacy protectionÂ [13, 14, 15, 16, 17]. A Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) is a secure and isolated computing environment that uses hardware and software encryption to protect sensitive data and ensure the accuracy of computations. It guarantees the confidentiality and integrity of an individual clientâ€™s application, even in an untrusted environmentÂ [18]. In FL, TEEs can be adopted by clients for local training and/or by central servers for secure aggregation of local updates to prevent attacks on the models or gradientsÂ [19, 20]. Differential privacy (DP)Â [21] is the de facto privacy mechanism that has been increasingly studied, including Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP, (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP, RÃ©nyi DP, and (Î±,Ïµ)ğ›¼italic-Ïµ(\alpha,\epsilon)-RÃ©nyi DPÂ [22, 23, 24, 25, 21]. InÂ [24], a time-varying noise perturbation mechanism was proposed, where a time-decaying noise was added to the model parameters. InÂ [25], information-theoretic bounds were derived to establish a connection between information leakage and DP.

DP mechanisms have been increasingly integrated into FL, aiming to learn a secure global model while providing privacy guarantees for local datasets. This allows the clients to efficiently train their local models with privacy protected according to local settings. TruexÂ et al.Â [26] proposed an FL system with local differential privacy (LDP) to ensure data privacy. The system can perform LDP-based perturbation on model parameter updating and sharing, according to the local privacy level. InÂ [27], a framework based on the DP was proposed to prevent information leakage by injecting noise to protect the privacy of the local model parameters. InÂ [28], three LDP mechanisms were developed to preserve privacy in different data analysis tasks. The LDP mechanisms were integrated into FL to predict traffic status, alleviate privacy threats, and reduce communications in crowd-sourcing applications. The above studies combined the local DP mechanisms with FL to address privacy issues. However, considerable noises are needed to perturb the local model parameters, reducing the efficiency and accuracy of FL.

The studies discussed above, i.e.,Â [26, 27, 28], have considered time-invariant DP noise perturbations; in other words, the variance of the DP perturbation noise remains persistent among global aggregations. This could require a long training or convergence time and degrade the learning performance, such as validation accuracyÂ [29]. On the other hand, there is clearly a potential to allow the variance of the DP perturbation noise to be adaptively configured and changed over different global aggregations, hence improving the learning performance of FL without compromising the privacy protection level. In particular, a small perturbation noise in the early stage of an FL process is expected to benefit convergenceÂ [30], as also observed experimentally in this paper.

This paper presents a new (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP amplitude-varying perturbation mechanism with a meticulously designed time-varying root-mean-square amplitude (or amplitude for short) of the perturbation noise to strike a balance between the privacy protection and the utility (i.e., loss and/or accuracy) of FL. The DP noise can be further adjusted online to combat the potential degradation of the utility, achieving effective learning while preserving privacy.

The key contributions are listed as follows.

  • â€¢

    We design the new (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP perturbation mechanism, where the variance (i.e., the square of the amplitude) of the DP noise is a geometric series changing over the global aggregations of the FL to provide privacy guarantees.

  • â€¢

    By privacy analysis, we derive the variance of the DP noise given the global aggregation number and privacy protection level of the FL. We also design the online adjustment of the variance and global aggregation rounds in the face of a model degradation of the FL.

  • â€¢

    An upper bound is derived for the loss of a multi-layer perceptron (MLP) model trained by FL running the new DP mechanism, establishing an analytical trade-off between the loss and privacy.

  • â€¢

    Based on the upper bound, an optimal number of global aggregations is identified to achieve the best utility of the FL and satisfy the privacy requirement.

Extensive experiments based on an MLP model show that the new DP mechanism with time-varying noise variance converges faster to better learning accuracy for a given privacy level, compared to the state-of-the-art noise perturbation with persistent variance, i.e., the Gaussian noise mechanismÂ [27]. Moreover, the new mechanism is readily applicable to other deep neural network (DNN) models, such as support vector machine (SVM) and convolutional neural network (CNN).

The remainder of this paper is arranged as follows. The system and threat models are provided in SectionÂ II. In SectionÂ III, we elaborate on the new DP mechanism, analyze its sensitivity and privacy, and the time-varying variance of the DP noise. SectionÂ IV derives the convergence upper bound of FL running the new DP mechanism, and the optimal number of global aggregations to achieve both convergence and privacy. Experimental results are discussed in SectionÂ V, followed by concluding remarks in SectionÂ VI.

II-B Threat Model

Suppose that the parameter server is honest but curious in the considered FL system. External attackers attempt to obtain confidential information of the users. Although the users can store and train their data locally in FL, the local model updates shared between the users and server can potentially compromise the privacy of the users, e.g., under inference attacks at the learning phaseÂ [31] and model-inversion attacks at the testing phaseÂ [6]. The attackers can hijack the private information by analyzing the global model parameters broadcast by the parameter server.

Assume that the attacker has a dataset ğ’Ÿasubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘{\cal D}_{a} overlapping with user kğ‘˜kâ€™s local dataset ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜{\cal D}_{k} and attempts to find the subset of its dataset, ğ’Ÿaâ€²âˆˆğ’Ÿasubscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²ğ‘subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘{\cal D}^{\prime}_{a}\in{\cal D}_{a}, that is the most likely used for the training of user kğ‘˜kâ€™s model, i.e., maxğ’Ÿaâ€²âˆˆğ’Ÿaâ¡Prâ¡[ğ’Ÿaâ€²âˆˆğ’Ÿk|ğk]subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²ğ‘subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘Prsubscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜subscriptğğ‘˜\max_{{\cal D}^{\prime}_{a}\in{\cal D}_{a}}\Pr\left[{\cal D}^{\prime}_{a}\in{\cal D}_{k}|\bm{\omega}_{k}\right]. Here, Prâ¡[ğ’Ÿaâ€²âˆˆğ’Ÿk|ğk]Prsubscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜subscriptğğ‘˜\Pr[{\cal D}^{\prime}_{a}\in{\cal D}_{k}|{\bm{\omega}}_{k}] is the probability that the subset ğ’Ÿaâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²ğ‘{\cal D}^{\prime}_{a} belongs to ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜{\cal D}_{k}, given user kğ‘˜kâ€™s model ğksubscriptğğ‘˜\bm{\omega}_{k}. It is possible that an attacker has an overlapping dataset with some participating nodes in an FL setting, which is a common assumption made in the literature when analyzing FL systems, e.g.,Â [31].

III Proposed DP Perturbation with Varying Noise Variance

In this section, we delineate the proposed DP mechanism with time-varying noise perturbation in the considered FL system, and analyze the sensitivity and privacy of the mechanism.

III-A Definition of DP

For an (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP mechanism, the privacy is parametrized by a requirement specified using Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon andÂ Î´ğ›¿\delta. Here, Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0 specifies the difference beyond which the outputs on two adjacent datasets ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} and ğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²{\cal D}^{\prime} can be differentiated111Two datasets, ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} and ğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²{\cal D}^{\prime}, are adjacent if ğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²{\cal D}^{\prime} can be built by inserting an example to, or discarding an example from, ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D}.. Î´ğ›¿\delta is the probability with which the ratio between the probabilities of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} and ğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²{\cal D}^{\prime} after DP noises are added is no smaller than expâ¡(Ïµ)italic-Ïµ\exp(\epsilon)Â [32]. The definition of the (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP is provided below.

Definition 1 ((Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DPÂ [14]).

for a measurable set ğ’®âŠ†â„›ğ’®â„›{\cal S}\subseteq{\cal R} and adjacent datasets ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²âˆˆğ’³ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²ğ’³{\cal D},{\cal D}^{\prime}\in{\cal X}.

III-B Proposed Time-varying Perturbation Noise Variance

We propose that the variance of the DP noise, i.e., Î˜â€‹(m)Î˜ğ‘š\varTheta(m), added to the local model parameters changes (increases or decreases), with the increasing number of global aggregations. On the one hand, for a required privacy level (e.g., (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta) in the context of DP), adding a smaller or stronger noise at the beginning of the training can speed up convergenceÂ [30]. On the other hand, more global aggregations in the training process result in worse privacy leakage since an adversary can observe more information exposed in the global aggregations and related to the training datasets, according toÂ [27].

We design that Î˜â€‹(m)Î˜ğ‘š\varTheta(m) is a geometric series, and the noise variance added in the mğ‘šm-th global aggregation is calculated as

Î˜â€‹(m)=Ï‘mâˆ’1â€‹Ïƒ2,m=1,â‹¯,M,formulae-sequenceÎ˜ğ‘šsuperscriptitalic-Ï‘ğ‘š1superscriptğœ2ğ‘š1â‹¯ğ‘€\varTheta(m)=\vartheta^{m-1}\sigma^{2},\;m=1,\cdots,M, (6)

where Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is the initial noise variance; Ï‘>0italic-Ï‘0\vartheta>0 is the scaling factor of the series. When Ï‘=1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta=1, the noise variance Î˜â€‹(m)Î˜ğ‘š\varTheta(m) remains unchanged, as it is in the existing DP schemesÂ [27].

Apart from the specific global model aggregation mğ‘šm, the DP noise variance Î˜â€‹(m)Î˜ğ‘š\varTheta(m) depends on the privacy level (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta), the ratio of participating users qğ‘q, the number of local update iterations between two global model aggregations Ï„ğœ\tau, and the iteration number Tğ‘‡T (or, in other words, the number of global model aggregations Mğ‘€M). It is of practical interest to determine the optimal values of Mğ‘€M and Ï„ğœ\tau, or their trade-off.

Remark 1.

TheoremÂ 1 indicates that a larger Ïƒğœ\sigma results in a smaller Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, i.e., a stronger privacy guarantee, and confirms that a larger Mğ‘€M leads to a higher likelihood of leaking private information during training, given Ïƒğœ\sigma. Based on TheoremÂ 1, given Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, Î´ğ›¿\delta, and Mğ‘€M, we adjust the DP noise variance to balance privacy preservation and the convergence of FL training.

Remark 2.

Given a privacy budget Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon for Mğ‘€M global aggregations, more clients involved in the model updates, i.e., a larger qğ‘q in (8), lead to requirements of stronger perturbation noises being added to the local model of each involved client. This indicates less privacy leakage for each client, which is consistent with the conclusion drawn inÂ [34].

It is consistent with the amplitude of the DP noise in a Gaussian noise perturbation mechanism developed inÂ [27].

III-D Online Adjustment of DP Perturbation Noise Amplitude

The aim of the proposed time-varying DP noise perturbation, i.e.,Â (8), is to protect the user privacy and ensure reasonable learning performance. As the global aggregation increases, however, the noise added in the late stage of the model training may degrade the learning performance.

To address this issue without compromising the (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP privacy level, we can reduce the maximum number of global aggregations, Mğ‘€M, and accordingly reduce the noise variance Ïƒm2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘š2\sigma_{m}^{2} at the mğ‘šm-th global aggregation. Here, Ïƒâ€²=Ïƒâ€²â€‹(Mâ€²,m)superscriptğœâ€²superscriptğœâ€²superscriptğ‘€â€²ğ‘š\sigma^{\prime}=\sigma^{\prime}(M^{\prime},m) depends on Mâ€²superscriptğ‘€â€²M^{\prime} and mğ‘šm, as given below.

Theorem 2.

Ideally, Mğ‘€M (or Mâ€²superscriptğ‘€â€²M^{\prime}) should be as large as possible to improve the accuracy of FL training. In this sense, the online adjustment of the DP noise variance is of practical interest, as it allows for a progressive increase in Mâ€²superscriptğ‘€â€²M^{\prime} adapting to the convergence process of FL and the remaining privacy budget. This is attractive for applications that require a balance between accuracy and privacy.

From Theorem 2, it is important to specify Mâ€²superscriptğ‘€â€²M^{\prime} and thenÂ Ïƒâ€²superscriptğœâ€²\sigma^{\prime} based onÂ (9). In practice, the aggregator may have part of the dataset for testing purpose. If the test loss function value at the aggregator stops decreasing, then a new Mâ€²superscriptğ‘€â€²M^{\prime} is calculated. An empirical approach is to set Mâ€²=âŒˆÎ±dâ€‹MâŒ‰superscriptğ‘€â€²subscriptğ›¼ğ‘‘ğ‘€M^{\prime}=\lceil\alpha_{d}M\rceil at the next global aggregation, whenever it is observed at a global aggregation that the global loss function stops decreasing. IV Convergence of Privacy-Preserving FL under DP with Time-varying Noise Amplitude

Corollary 1.

CorollaryÂ 1 shows the trade-off between the learning performance and privacy protection level. In the case of a weak privacy guarantee (i.e., both Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon and Î´ğ›¿\delta are large), the convergence upper bound is tighter since the second term on the right-hand side (RHS) ofÂ (12) approaches zero. Additionally, the convergence upper bound inÂ (12) is unrestricted by the partition of the data among the users. The data partition is captured in the gradient divergence Î³ğ›¾\gamma, a parameter of â„‹â€‹(Ï„)â„‹ğœ{\cal H}\left(\tau\right); see LemmaÂ 1. Since âˆ‚â„‹â€‹(Ï„)âˆ‚M=âˆ‚â„‹â€‹(TM)âˆ‚M=âˆ’Î³â€‹TM2â€‹(Î·â€‹L+1)TMâ€‹lnâ¡(Î·â€‹L+1)+Î³â€‹TM2â‰¤0â„‹ğœğ‘€â„‹ğ‘‡ğ‘€ğ‘€ğ›¾ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘€2superscriptğœ‚ğ¿1ğ‘‡ğ‘€ğœ‚ğ¿1ğ›¾ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘€20\frac{\partial{\cal H}\left(\tau\right)}{\partial M}=\frac{\partial{\cal H}\left(\frac{T}{M}\right)}{\partial M}=-\frac{\gamma T}{M^{2}}\left(\eta L+1\right)^{\frac{T}{M}}\ln\left(\eta L+1\right)+\frac{\gamma T}{M^{2}}\leq 0 for Mâ‰¤Tlnâ¡(Î·/lnâ¡(Î·â€‹L+1))ğ‘€ğ‘‡ğœ‚ğœ‚ğ¿1M\leq\frac{T}{\ln\left(\eta/\ln\left(\eta L+1\right)\right)}, the upper bound becomes smaller when Mğ‘€M is larger and Î³ğ›¾\gamma is smaller under a given Tğ‘‡T.

Another interesting finding in TheoremÂ 3 is that the convergence upper bound is not a monotonic function of either Tğ‘‡T or Mğ‘€M, as established in the following CorollaryÂ 2.

Corollary 2.

Given Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon and Î´ğ›¿\delta, the convergence upper bound is convex in the number of iterations or global aggregations, i.e., Tğ‘‡T or Mğ‘€M, if Ï‘â‰¥ğ’œitalic-Ï‘ğ’œ\vartheta\geq{\cal A} and Ï„â‰¥lnâ¡(Î·/lnâ¡(Î·â€‹L+1))lnâ¡(Î·â€‹L+1)ğœğœ‚ğœ‚ğ¿1ğœ‚ğ¿1\tau\geq\frac{\ln\left(\eta/\ln\left(\eta L+1\right)\right)}{\ln\left(\eta L+1\right)}.

Proof.

See AppendixÂ D. âˆ

Note that the upper bound in (12) may not be tight, as it is obtained through the use of the triangular inequality and Jensenâ€™s inequality, which are commonly used in the derivation of convergence upper bounds for FL models [8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13]. Despite this, the upper bound reveals that the optimality gap of an FL model under our proposed perturbation mechanism would decrease at first, and then increase as the number of global aggregations increases. This confirms that FL models can diverge, rather than converge, due to noise perturbation for differential privacy, and highlights the existence of an optimal number of global aggregations; i.e., Tğ‘‡T or Mğ‘€M can be optimized to minimize the loss function.

Also note that Theorem 3, and Corollaries 1 and 2 are based on the smoothness of the loss functions of the neural network models being trained, and applicable to the convergence bound analysis of FL systems training MLP and SVM models. On the other hand, Theorems 1 and 2 specify the DP noise variances to preserve the privacy of an FL training process and defer the divergence of the process caused by the DP noises. The two theorems do not rely on the smoothness of the loss functions, and are applicable to neural networks with non-smooth loss functions, e.g., CNN.

The optimal number of global aggregations, denoted by Mâˆ—superscriptğ‘€M^{*}, can be found numericallyÂ [38], e.g., using bisection search. According to CorollaryÂ 2, the convergence upper bound is convex with respect to Mğ‘€M, if Ï‘â‰¥ğ’œitalic-Ï‘ğ’œ\vartheta\geq{\cal A} and Ï„â‰¥lnâ¡(Î·/lnâ¡(Î·â€‹L+1))lnâ¡(Î·â€‹L+1)ğœğœ‚ğœ‚ğ¿1ğœ‚ğ¿1\tau\geq\frac{\ln\left(\eta/\ln\left(\eta L+1\right)\right)}{\ln\left(\eta L+1\right)}. Then, the solution to (14) is unique and globally optimal. The value of Ï„ğœ\tau is determined by the ratio of Tğ‘‡T to Mğ‘€M. Here, given Tğ‘‡T, we determine Mğ‘€M. Accordingly, Ï„=T/Mğœğ‘‡ğ‘€\tau=T/M is updated.

V Experimental Results

This section assesses the accuracy of our analysis and the effectiveness of the proposed time-varying DP noise variance for distributed gradient descent-based FL under various learning tasks, models, and real-world datasets.

V-A Experimental Settings

We set the number of users to U=100ğ‘ˆ100U=100, the number of chosen users to K=10ğ¾10K=10, and the number of iterations between two consecutive global aggregations to Ï„=5ğœ5\tau=5. With reference toÂ [27], we set the clipping threshold C=5ğ¶5C=5, and Î´=0.001ğ›¿0.001\delta=0.001. The maximum number of global aggregations is M=30ğ‘€30M=30 and the privacy protection level is Ïµ=10italic-Ïµ10\epsilon=10; unless otherwise specified. The experiments are conducted on four datasets:

  • â€¢

    The standard MNIST dataset comprises 60,000 training and 10,000 testing examples, which are grayscale images of handwritten digits from one to ten;

  • â€¢

    The ADULT dataset, which contains 40,000 records extracted from census dataÂ [39] and each record has up to 58 attributes, including age, education, etc.;

  • â€¢

    The CIFAR10 dataset, which contains 60,000 32Ã—32323232\times 32 color images in ten classes (6,000 per class), 50,000 for training and 10,000 for testing; and

  • â€¢

    The Fashion-MNIST (FMNIST) dataset, which contains Zalandoâ€™s article images (i.e., 28Ã—28282828\times 28 grayscale images) in ten classes, including 60,000 examples for training and 10,000 examples for testing.

We evaluate the proposed DP mechanism with time-varying perturbation noise variance on MLP, SVM, and CNN models.

V-B Evaluation of the Distributed Gradient Descent Time-Varying DP Algorithm on MLP

The MLP is a fully-connected feedforward neural network. We consider an MLP model comprising a hidden layer and 32 hidden units, and train the model on the MNIST dataset. We adopt linear activation functions and softmax of ten classes that correspond to the ten digits. The modelâ€™s error on the local training dataset is measured by a cross-entropy loss function.

V-B1 Impact of Noise Scaling Factor Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta

Fig.Â 2 evaluates the impact of the proposed DP mechanism with time-varying perturbation noise variance on the convergence of FL, where the xğ‘¥x-axis provides the index to the global aggregations mğ‘šm. Here, mâ‰¤M=30ğ‘šğ‘€30m\leq M=30, since using a value of mğ‘šm larger than Mğ‘€M would violate the privacy requirements and render the values of the training accuracy meaningless. Different Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta values are assessed, where Ï‘=1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta=1 can be viewed as the state-of-the-art design of the DP perturbation noise developed inÂ [27]. Each curve in a figure corresponds to a standalone experiment of a training process given Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon.

Fig.Â 2(a) shows that given the privacy level, the number of global aggregations needed for the (testing) loss function value to reach its minimum generally declines, as Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta rises from 0.9 to 1.1. In the case of Ï‘>1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta>1, the minimum of the loss function first declines and then increases. This is because the noise added in the early learning stage of the learning is smaller in the case of Ï‘>1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta>1 than it is in the case of Ï‘=1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta=1, leading to faster convergence. Moreover, the noise rises exponentially and leads to an increase in the loss function value with the growth of mğ‘šm. In the case of Ï‘<1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta<1, the loss function value is large in the early learning stage and declines with the growth of mğ‘šm. The loss function value also decreases, as Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta increases from 0.90.90.9 to 0.950.950.95. This is because the noise added in the early stage is larger for a smaller Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta, causing slower convergence.

Fig.Â 2(b) plots the (testing) accuracy of the proposed algorithm under different Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta values. Similar to the loss function value, given the privacy level, the aggregation numbers required to reach the maximum accuracy decrease as Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta increases from 0.9 to 1.1. The accuracy is more stable and remains unchanged under a smaller Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta value. In contrast, the accuracy quickly reaches its peak and declines slowly under a larger Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta value since a smaller noise is added in the early learning stages of the model training process and leads to faster convergence given Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. With the increase of global aggregations, the noises added to the model parameters grow exponentially, resulting in accuracy degradation. To this end, the value of Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta can be adequately configured to achieve better convergence and satisfy the DP requirement in the FL process with the proposed time-varying DP perturbation noise variances.

Fig.Â 3 evaluates the impact of the proposed DP mechanism with time-varying perturbation noise variance on the utility (i.e., the loss function and accuracy) of FL, as the total number of global aggregations, Mğ‘€M, increases. Each point in a figure corresponds to a standalone experiment of a training process given Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. The initial amplitude of the DP noise is calibrated for each point based on the given value of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon; see the second row of Tab.Â II.

Fig.Â 3(a) shows that the loss function of the MLP exhibits convex curvature with respect to Mğ‘€M, as is consistent with CorollaryÂ 2. The loss functions achieve their minimums under the optimal number of global aggregations, Mâˆ—=17superscriptğ‘€17M^{*}=17, for all considered Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta values, validating the result in SectionÂ IV-C. The third row of Tab.Â II provides the corresponding minimum loss function values. Fig.Â 3(a) and Tab.Â II reveal that both the time-increasing noise perturbation (Ï‘=1.05italic-Ï‘1.05\vartheta=1.05) and the time-decreasing noise perturbation (Ï‘=0.95italic-Ï‘0.95\vartheta=0.95) can outperform the time-invariant noise perturbation (Ï‘=1.0italic-Ï‘1.0\vartheta=1.0) in terms of loss at their respective optimal numbers of global aggregations.

Fig.Â 3(b) plots the (testing) accuracy of the proposed algorithm against Mğ‘€M, where different values of Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta are considered. Consistent with Fig.Â 3(a), the optimal Mâˆ—superscriptğ‘€M^{*} values achieve the best accuracy in all experiments. We also see that when Ï‘â‰ 1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta\neq 1, a large number of global aggregations M>Mâˆ—ğ‘€superscriptğ‘€M>M^{*} could overkill the learning accuracy, especially when Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta is big, e.g., Ï‘=1.1italic-Ï‘1.1\vartheta=1.1. One can potentially select the optimal Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta value to achieve the optimal learning accuracy. In the example of Fig.Â 3, the configuration of Ï‘â‰¥1.05italic-Ï‘1.05\vartheta\geq 1.05 allows for the smallest loss and highest accuracy of the learning. As observed in Fig.Â 3, all curves diverge, i.e., convex in Fig.Â 3(a) and concave in Fig.Â 3(b), even when Ï‘=1.0italic-Ï‘1.0\vartheta=1.0. This is because the local models are still perturbed by the DP noises with a persistent DP noise variance, when Ï‘=1.0italic-Ï‘1.0\vartheta=1.0.

Figs.Â 2 and 3 also compare our proposed DP mechanism with time-varying perturbation noise variance to the Laplacian mechanism (with a constant noise variance)Â [40]. Except for the DP mechanisms, all curves are under consistent experimental parameter settings in the figures. It is observed that the FL performance is worse under the Laplacian mechanism than it is under our proposed Gaussian mechanism with a time-varying DP noise variance. This is because the Laplacian mechanism adds larger noises to the data by sampling from a Laplacian distribution, which has a higher likelihood of sampling values that are farther away from the mean.

V-B2 Impact of Privacy Protection Level Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon

We evaluate the impact of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon on the utility of the FL protected by the proposed DP mechanism with time-varying perturbation noise variance. According to SectionÂ V-B1, we set Ï‘=1.05italic-Ï‘1.05\vartheta=1.05. Fig.Â 4 evaluates the loss of the learning with the growth of Mğ‘€M under different settings of the privacy level Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. For comparison, we also plot the case with no DP noise perturbation, i.e., Ïµâ†’âˆâ†’italic-Ïµ\epsilon\to\infty. Figs.Â 4(a) andÂ 4(b) show that the loss function value is convex and the accuracy is concave with respect to Mğ‘€M, which is in line with CorollaryÂ 2. In general, the optimal number of global aggregations Mâˆ—superscriptğ‘€M^{*} increases withÂ Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon.

Fig.Â 4(a) also shows that the loss function values decrease and approach the case with no DP noise perturbation, as Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon increases. Fig.Â 4(b) shows that increasing Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon can improve the accuracy. In the case that the privacy level is larger than 20, i.e., Ïµâ‰¥20italic-Ïµ20\epsilon\geq 20, the convergence performance approaches the case without noise perturbation. This is because, with a lower privacy protection level Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, the DP noises with a larger variance are injected in the first global aggregation according to TheoremÂ 1, resulting in larger loss function values. A trade-off arises between the learning performance (i.e., loss and accuracy) and privacy level, and can be adjusted throughÂ Mâˆ—superscriptğ‘€M^{*}.

V-B3 Online Adjustment of DP Noise Variance

We evaluate the online adjustment of the aggregation number and DP noise variance proposed in SectionÂ III-D. Figs.Â 5 andÂ 6 plot the updated maximum number of global aggregations, i.e., Mâ€²superscriptğ‘€â€²M^{\prime}, the loss function value, and the accuracy under different values of Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta when Î±d=0.8subscriptğ›¼ğ‘‘0.8\alpha_{d}=0.8 and 0.90.90.9. As shown in Fig.Â 5, the maximum number of global aggregations Mâ€²superscriptğ‘€â€²M^{\prime} decreases over mğ‘šm, resulting from the updating of Ïƒmsubscriptğœğ‘š\sigma_{m} to keep the global loss function decreasing, and meanwhile, the privacy protection level Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon satisfied. As shown in Figs.Â 6(a) andÂ 6(c), the loss function value decreases with the increase of Mğ‘€M under all considered Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta values. Among all four curves, Ï‘=1.05italic-Ï‘1.05\vartheta=1.05 provides the best learning performance when Î±d=0.8subscriptğ›¼ğ‘‘0.8\alpha_{d}=0.8, as shown in Figs.Â 6(a) and 6(b), and Ï‘=1.1italic-Ï‘1.1\vartheta=1.1 provides the best learning performance when Î±d=0.9subscriptğ›¼ğ‘‘0.9\alpha_{d}=0.9, as shown in Figs.Â 6(c) andÂ 6(d). Compared to the results without online adjustment of the DP noise variance, i.e., Figs.Â 3(a) andÂ 3(b), the online adjustment of the DP noise variance can improve the learning performance of both the loss and accuracy in the case of Ï‘â‰¥1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta\geq 1; see Fig.Â 6.

V-B4 Defence against Membership Inference Attacks

TableÂ III evaluates the effectiveness of the proposed method in defending against membership inference attacks, which aim to determine whether a specific data point was used in training the model. The results indicate that without the mechanism, the attack success rate of the membership inference attack can be as high as 99.3%. By contrast, when the mechanism is employed, the attack success rate drops significantly, e.g., by about 40% to less than 60% when Ï‘=1.05italic-Ï‘1.05\vartheta=1.05.

V-C Extension to SVM and CNN models

The proposed DP mechanism with time-varying perturbation noise can be readily applied to SVM and CNN models:

  • â€¢

    The SVM model is trained using a standard quadratic optimization algorithm on the ADULT dataset. The loss function is Fâ€‹(ğ)=Î»r2â€‹â€–ğâ€–22+maxâ¡{0,Î²nâˆ’ğTâ€‹ğ’Ÿk,n}ğ¹ğsubscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ2superscriptsubscriptnormğ220subscriptğ›½ğ‘›superscriptğğ‘‡subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘›F({\bm{\omega}})=\frac{\lambda_{r}}{2}\left\|{\bm{\omega}}\right\|_{2}^{2}+\max\left\{0,\;\beta_{n}-{\bm{\omega}}^{T}{\cal D}_{k,n}\right\}, where Î»r>0subscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ0\lambda_{r}>0 is a regularization coefficient; ğ’Ÿk,nsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘›{\cal D}_{k,n} is the nğ‘›n-th sample in ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜{\cal D}_{k}, i.e., the dataset at the kğ‘˜k-th user; and Î²nâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}subscriptğ›½ğ‘›11\beta_{n}\in\{-1,1\} for n=1,â‹¯,|ğ’Ÿk|ğ‘›1â‹¯subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜n=1,\cdots,\left|{\cal D}_{k}\right|.

  • â€¢

    The CNN model contains two convolutional layers with a kernel size of five and three fully-connected layers. The CNN model is trained separately on the CIFAR10 and FMNIST datasets. We adopt the ReLU units and softmax of ten classes for the ten classes of the CIFAR10 and the ten digits of the FMNIST. The CNN model is trained using the SGD to minimize the loss function.

Figs.Â 7(a) andÂ 7(b) plot the (testing) loss function and accuracy of the FL of the SVM model on the ADULT dataset under the proposed DP mechanism with time-varying perturbation noise variance. Figs.Â 8(a)Â andÂ 8(b) plot those of the CNN model on the CIFAR10 dataset. Figs.Â 8(c) andÂ 8(d) plot those of the CNN model on the FMNIST dataset.

Consistent with the observations made under the MLP model in SectionÂ V-B, there exists the optimal number of global aggregations, Mâˆ—superscriptğ‘€M^{*}, that minimizes the loss function of the SVM and CNN models (and maximizes their accuracy) while satisfying the (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP privacy level. The value of Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta can also be configured to positively impact the utility of FL.

On the other hand, Figs.Â 7(a) andÂ 7(b) show that the time-increasing noise perturbation (Ï‘>1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta>1) achieves the best learning performance (i.e., achievable smallest loss and best accuracy), followed by the time-invariant noise perturbation (Ï‘=1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta=1) and then time-decreasing noise perturbation (Ï‘<1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta<1) on the SVM model. The time-decreasing noise perturbation (Ï‘<1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta<1) performs the best on the CNN models under both of the considered datasets. In contrast, Ï‘>1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta>1 is the best, followed by Ï‘<1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta<1, and Ï‘=1italic-Ï‘1\vartheta=1 is the worst on the MLP model; see Fig.Â 3(a). This is due to the distinct network architectures of the MLP, SVM, and CNN models.

Fig.Â 9 illustrates the effect of increasing the maximum allowed number of global aggregations, Mğ‘€M, on the loss and accuracy of the learning process for different values of the privacy parameter, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. The figure is based on the SVM model and the ADULT dataset, where Ï‘=1.05italic-Ï‘1.05\vartheta=1.05 and M=50ğ‘€50M=50. Each curve in the figure represents the results of a standalone training process with a given Ï‘italic-Ï‘\vartheta and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. It is observed in Fig.Â 9 that as Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon increases, the loss function values decrease and approach the case with no DP noise perturbation (i.e., Ïµâ†’âˆâ†’italic-Ïµ\epsilon\to\infty). Increasing Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon can also lead to improved accuracy. It is also observed that the FL does not diverge under Ïµâ†’âˆâ†’italic-Ïµ\epsilon\rightarrow\infty, as opposed to the rest of the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon values. This is because when Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon goes to infinity, no privacy is required and the FL considered is expected to behave like regular FedAvg.

Fig.Â 10 plots the (testing) loss and accuracy of the CNN models on the CIFAR10 and FMNIST datasets under different settings of the privacy level Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. We see that the loss functions of the CNN models are also convex with respect to Mğ‘€M, which is in line with CorollaryÂ 2 and the observations made on the MLP model in SectionÂ V-B. It is also seen that, as Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon increases, the loss function values decrease. The optimal number of global aggregations Mâˆ—superscriptğ‘€M^{*} also increases. This is also consistent with the observations made on the MLP model in SectionÂ V-B.

VI Conclusion

This paper has proposed and analyzed a new DP mechanism with a time-varying noise amplitude to balance the privacy and utility of FL. We have established the varying amplitude as a function of the maximum number of global aggregations and the privacy protection levels. We have also derived a convergence upper bound for the loss function of MLP models protected by the new mechanism, revealing a trade-off between the loss and privacy. The number of global aggregations has been optimized based on the upper bound. Extensive experiments have assessed the convergence and utility of three different ML models trained using FL and protected by the new DP mechanism. The new DP mechanism with time-varying noise amplitudes has been seen to exhibit faster convergence and better accuracy under given privacy protection levels, compared to existing solutions.

lnâ¡(1Î´)1ğ›¿\displaystyle\ln\left(\!\frac{1}{\delta}\!\right) â‰¤qâ€‹(Î”â€‹s)2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’Ï‘1âˆ’M)2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’1)â€‹(12âˆ’Ïµâ€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’1)Î”â€‹s2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’Ï‘1âˆ’M))2absentğ‘superscriptÎ”ğ‘ 2italic-Ï‘superscriptitalic-Ï‘1ğ‘€2superscriptğœ2italic-Ï‘1superscript12italic-Ïµsuperscriptğœ2italic-Ï‘1Î”superscriptğ‘ 2italic-Ï‘superscriptitalic-Ï‘1ğ‘€2\displaystyle\!\leq\!\frac{q(\Delta s)^{2}(\vartheta-\vartheta^{1-M})}{2\sigma^{2}(\vartheta-1)}\left(\!\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\epsilon\sigma^{2}(\vartheta-1)}{\Delta s^{2}(\vartheta-\vartheta^{1-M})}\!\right)^{2} (23)
=\displaystyle= qâ€‹(Î”â€‹s)2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’Ï‘1âˆ’M)8â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’1)+Ïµ2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’1)2â€‹qâ€‹Î”â€‹s2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’Ï‘1âˆ’M)âˆ’Ïµ2.ğ‘superscriptÎ”ğ‘ 2italic-Ï‘superscriptitalic-Ï‘1ğ‘€8superscriptğœ2italic-Ï‘1superscriptitalic-Ïµ2superscriptğœ2italic-Ï‘12ğ‘Î”superscriptğ‘ 2italic-Ï‘superscriptitalic-Ï‘1ğ‘€italic-Ïµ2\displaystyle\frac{q(\Delta s)^{2}(\vartheta-\vartheta^{1-M})}{8\sigma^{2}(\vartheta-1)}+\frac{\epsilon^{2}\sigma^{2}(\vartheta-1)}{2q\Delta s^{2}(\vartheta-\vartheta^{1-M})}-\frac{\epsilon}{2}.

Since Î´âˆˆ(0,1]ğ›¿01\delta\in(0,1] and lnâ¡(Î´)â‰¤0ğ›¿0\ln(\delta)\leq 0, fromÂ (17) we have

qâ€‹Î»â€‹(Î»+1)â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’Ï‘1âˆ’M)â€‹(Î”â€‹s)22â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’1)â€‹Ïƒ2âˆ’Î»â€‹Ïµâ‰¤0.ğ‘ğœ†ğœ†1italic-Ï‘superscriptitalic-Ï‘1ğ‘€superscriptÎ”ğ‘ 22italic-Ï‘1superscriptğœ2ğœ†italic-Ïµ0\frac{q\lambda(\lambda+1)(\vartheta-\vartheta^{1-M})(\Delta s)^{2}}{2(\vartheta-1)\sigma^{2}}-\lambda\epsilon\leq 0. (24)

By substituting Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} in (19) intoÂ (24), we have

qâ€‹(Î”â€‹s)2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’Ï‘1âˆ’M)8â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’1)â‰¤Ïµ4.ğ‘superscriptÎ”ğ‘ 2italic-Ï‘superscriptitalic-Ï‘1ğ‘€8superscriptğœ2italic-Ï‘1italic-Ïµ4\frac{q(\Delta s)^{2}(\vartheta-\vartheta^{1-M})}{8\sigma^{2}(\vartheta-1)}\leq{\frac{\epsilon}{4}}. (25)

lnâ¡(1Î´)â‰¤Ïµ2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’1)2â€‹qâ€‹(Î”â€‹s)2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’Ï‘1âˆ’M)âˆ’Ïµ4â‰¤Ïµ2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’1)2â€‹qâ€‹Î”â€‹s2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’Ï‘1âˆ’M).1ğ›¿superscriptitalic-Ïµ2superscriptğœ2italic-Ï‘12ğ‘superscriptÎ”ğ‘ 2italic-Ï‘superscriptitalic-Ï‘1ğ‘€italic-Ïµ4superscriptitalic-Ïµ2superscriptğœ2italic-Ï‘12ğ‘Î”superscriptğ‘ 2italic-Ï‘superscriptitalic-Ï‘1ğ‘€\ln\left(\frac{1}{\delta}\right)\leq\frac{\epsilon^{2}\sigma^{2}(\vartheta-1)}{2q(\Delta s)^{2}(\vartheta-\vartheta^{1-M})}-\frac{\epsilon}{4}\leq\frac{\epsilon^{2}\sigma^{2}(\vartheta-1)}{2q\Delta s^{2}(\vartheta-\vartheta^{1-M})}. (26)

To ensure the (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP of the considered FL system, we choose Ïƒğœ\sigma that satisfies

Ïƒ2â‰¤2â€‹qâ€‹(Î”â€‹s)2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’Ï‘1âˆ’M)Ïµ2â€‹(Ï‘âˆ’1)â€‹lnâ¡(1Î´).superscriptğœ22ğ‘superscriptÎ”ğ‘ 2italic-Ï‘superscriptitalic-Ï‘1ğ‘€superscriptitalic-Ïµ2italic-Ï‘11ğ›¿\sigma^{2}\leq\frac{2q(\Delta s)^{2}(\vartheta-\vartheta^{1-M})}{\epsilon^{2}(\vartheta-1)}\ln\left(\frac{1}{\delta}\right). (27)

This concludes the proof of the theorem.
